head.title: kcgi | minimal CGI library for C

body.header:
kcgi — minimal CGI library for C
version @VERSION@ Sources Archives

article.p: kcgi is a minimal CGI library for web applications (HTML and HTTP) in ISC licensed ISO C. It was designed to be secure and auditable. See a Comparison of CGI Libraries in C for alternatives. To start, download kcgi.tgz and run make install into your PREFIX of choice. The kcgi(3) manpage documents usage. kcgi is a BSD.lv project.

div.p: Process separation of parse context. Now, khttp_parse forks a child process to parse input data, which returns well-defined results to the parent over a socketpair. Moreover, khttp_parse does not exit on failure, but instead returns an error to the caller. Audited all other kcgi internal functions so that they don't exit on failure, but return an error code to the caller. For consistency with OpenBSD, kxrealloc and krealloc have been renamed krealloc and kreallocarray, respectively. Finally, khtml_template has been renamed to khttp_template as it can be used in a non-HTML context just as well. A related function, khttp_template_buf, was added to supplement khttp_template with a buffer-input version.

article.p: The following is a rough feature list of kcgi. See the manual for details.

ul.li: input: parse and validate query string, cookie, and form input
functions: pretty-print HTML5 trees, output HTTP headers, format URLs
templating: populate file templates with callbacks

article.p: Most kcgi applications work as follows (the sample.c file distributed in the source consists of a full working example):

ol.li: Call khttp_parse as early as possible. This will parse forms, query, and cookie data; validate fields; set up the HTTP environment; and map page and MIME requests. Validation uses kvalid_double, kvalid_email, kvalid_int, kvalid_string, kvalid_udouble, kvalid_uint, or locally-defined functions for validation.
Examine the struct kpair elements of the struct kreq structure and potentially perform high-level, database-driven revalidation. This structure contains all elements parsed by khttp_parse.
Emit HTTP headers with khttp_head, followed by khttp_body to begin the HTTP body. The latter will automatically trigger compression if requested by the client.
Emit HTTP body output using HTML5 tree-building functions khtml_attr, khtml_attrx, khtml_close, khtml_closeto, khtml_elem, khtml_elemat, khtml_entity, khtml_int, khtml_ncr, or khtml_text; or
use the khttp_template function to populate file templates; or
Call khttp_free to close the HTTP document and free all memory.

article.p: This library is still quite new. Contact Kristaps with questions or comments.

As a security precaution, the kcgi library parses untrusted network data in a child process. When invoked, khttp_parse will fork. The child process is responsible for reading and parsing form data from the web server. This parsed data is returned to the parent process over a socketpair.
Originally, the OpenBSD imsg approach was used, but this is constrained in message size due to the underlying SOCK_DGRAM usage. The socket communication in kcgi uses SOCK_STREAM.

If HAVE_ZLIB is enabled during compilation (via the Makefile), khttp_body will signal use of zlib to compress the HTTP body. Compression is only enabled if the client provides the correct (gzip) HTTP request header.

All common input methods—query string, cookie, and form (multipart form-data and mixed, urlencoded, and plain—are supported by kcgi. As described in the Security section, these fields are all parsed from network data in a child process. Each input key-value pair can be matched (by key name) to a validator, which is run when fields are parsed. You can then look up key-value pairs constant-time in a table indexed by that key.
kcgi provides just the necessary functions for building HTML5 trees, outputting HTTP headers, and building URLs to get by. As a convenience, it also provides memory allocation wrappers.

While you can build HTML5 trees as noted in Functions, most application will want just to fill in a template. kcgi provides a simple function, khttp_template, to fill in flat-files found in the file-system.
